name: Field Bindweed
overview: Flowering occurs in the mid-summer. funnel-shaped flowers develop, its coloring goes from white to pale pink. As a creeping hemiparasite, it lives multiple years and is able to grow up higher and higher. Because of this, it can choke out other plants and causes harm to the environment. It does this by out competing other plants for sunlight moisture and nutrients. It is difficult to remove because of the extensive root system, but shading the plant through paper, straw, or wood chips can control the species.
habitat: This is an annual climbing herb is not native to California and, is confined to western North America. It is native to Europe and Asia, it was introduced to western North America most likely as a contaminant in crop seed in the 1700s. This invasive species prefers roadsides, grasslands, and along streams.
tags: Convolvulus arvensis Field Bindweed  withy wind smallflowered morning glory creeping jenny white flower plant flower
